question: Question_05_(b)
statement:
Define a sequence \emph{x}\textsubscript{0}, \emph{x}\textsubscript{1},
... by the initial conditions \emph{x}\textsubscript{0} = \emph{a},
\emph{x}\textsubscript{1} = \emph{b} and \emph{x}\textsubscript{2} =
\emph{c} together with the recursion relation

\[\displaystyle
x_{n+3} = x_{n+2} + x_{n+1} + x_n\]

for \emph{n} = 0, 1, 2, ...

\textbf{(b)} If the matrix \emph{A} from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_05_(a)}{part
(a)} is defined in MATLAB/Octave, we can do the following calculations

\texttt{\textgreater{}eig(A)}\\\texttt{ans~=~}\\\texttt{~~~~~1.83929~+~0.00000i}\\\texttt{~~~~-0.41964~+~0.60629i}\\\texttt{~~~~-0.41964~-~0.60629i}

\texttt{\textgreater{}abs(eig(A))}\\\texttt{ans~=}\\\texttt{~~~~~1.83929}\\\texttt{~~~~~0.73735}\\\texttt{~~~~~0.73735}

Describe how you could make further use of the \emph{eig} command and
other MATLAB/Octave commands to determine all (possibly complex) initial
values \emph{a}, \emph{b} and \emph{c} for which $x_n \to 0$ as
$n \to \infty$.
sols:
First, we notice that the recursion relation \emph{X\textsubscript{n+1}
= AX\textsubscript{n}} implies that

\[X_{n+1} = AX_n = A(AX_{n-1}) = A(A(AX_{-2})) = \ldots = A^{n+1}X_0\]

Since \emph{A} is a \emph{3×3} matrix with three distinct eigenvalues
\emph{λ\textsubscript{1} = 1.83929}, \emph{λ\textsubscript{2} = -0.41964
+ 0.60629i}, \emph{λ\textsubscript{3} = -0.41964 + 0.60629i} there is a
basis of corresponding eigenvectors \emph{v\textsubscript{1}},
\emph{v\textsubscript{2}}, \emph{v\textsubscript{3}}. Let us rewrite
\emph{X\textsubscript{0}} with respect to this basis:

\[\displaystyle
X_0 = \alpha v_1 + \beta v_2 + \gamma v_3\]

Then

\begin{align*}
X_{n+1} &= A^{n+1}X_0 = A^{n+1}(\alpha v_1 + \beta v_2 + \gamma v_3) \\
&= \alpha A^{n+1}v_1 + \beta A^{n+1}v_2 + \gamma A^{n+1}v_3 \\
&= \alpha \lambda_1^{n+1}v_1 + \beta \lambda_2^{n+1}v_2 + \gamma \lambda_3^{n+1}v_3
\end{align*}

Now we see that the last two terms will vanish as \emph{n} goes to
infinity, because $|\lambda_2|<1$ and $|\lambda_3|<1$. However, since
$|\lambda_1|>1$ the norm of the first vector will blow up as \emph{n}
approaches infinity, \textbf{unless \emph{α = 0}}.

This is the key to this question: As long as the vector with the initial
conditions, $X_0 = \begin{bmatrix} c \\ b \\ a \end{bmatrix}$ lies in
the plane that is spanned by \emph{v\textsubscript{2}} and
\emph{v\textsubscript{3}} but has no component in direction of
\emph{v\textsubscript{1}}, then the sequence will converge to zero:
\emph{x\textsubscript{n} → 0} as \emph{n → $\infty$}. Eigenvectors
\emph{v\textsubscript{2}} and \emph{v\textsubscript{3}} can be obtained
in MATLAB/Octave with

\texttt{~~~{[}V,D{]}~=~eig(A);~~\%~V~is~a~matrix~with~eigenvectors~in~its~columns}\\\texttt{~~~v\_2~=~V{[}:,2{]};}\\\texttt{~~~v\_3~=~V{[}:,3{]};}

Then the initial values that imply \emph{x\textsubscript{n} → 0} as
\emph{n → $\infty$} are

\[\left\{\begin{bmatrix} c \\ b \\ a \end{bmatrix} \text{ such that } \begin{bmatrix} c \\ b \\ a \end{bmatrix} = s v_2 + t v_3 \text{ for some } s, t \in \mathbb{C}\right\}\]
hints:
Write the vector of initial conditions \emph{X\textsubscript{0}} as a
linear combination of the eigenvectors, then apply
\emph{A\textsuperscript{n+1}} to each of those.
